alert.note: Alert for Central Interior; Deltana and Tanana Flats; Denali; Eastern Alaska Range; Middle Tanana Valley; Southeastern Brooks Range; Upper Koyukuk Valley; Upper Tanana Valley and the Fortymile Country; Yukon Flats and Surrounding Uplands (Alaska) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.headline: Special Weather Statement issued May 07 at 1:36PM AKDT by NWS Fairbanks
info.description: ...Snowmelt Flooding Possible Later This Week... All areas of Northern Alaska will see a warming trend to near or just above normal temperatures in the second half of this week. These warming temperatures, combined with a much above normal snowpack over most of the Interior, will cause a significant increase in snowmelt and push of water into drainage areas and rivers south of the Brooks Range late this week. People who live near areas prone to snowmelt flooding, should prepare for the possibility of snowmelt flooding later this week. Although most of the snow in Fairbanks and other low elevation areas has melted, elevations above 1000 feet have most of the winter snowpack remaining. Flooding is not expected in Fairbanks, but areas draining elevations above 1000 feet will see a large increase in water in the second half of this week. The chance of breakup and/or snow melt flooding are above normal this spring over eastern Alaska and are about a week later than normal. The latest breakup information is available at www.weather.gov/aprfc/breakupMap.
